139 gtan phebs|SANST explained by {khrig khrig byas tshar pa} {gtan la phebs} published after being thoroughly revised or completely got ready.
139 gu yog|1. {bya'i rgyal po zhig} n. of a king of birds (K. my. 18). 2. n. of the second son of Jengis Khan, who ruled over Eastern Mongolia.

139 kang ka|‡ SANST, SANST 1. a crane. 2. in Tibet a bird that feeds on dead bodies and is therefore called {dur bya} the bird of the cemetery.
139 ka rtsam|a species of wild oats; it differs from the yug-po or Tibetan oats and is considered superior to buckwheat, but inferior to wheat.
139 kha lkug|dumb; also of indistinct speech: {ra yi mcher pas byis pa'i kha lkug 'byed} the spleen of a goat removes the dumbness of children.

141 yams|or {yams nad} epidemic or infectious disease, one being called {yams nad} and the other {dal yams} slowly or steadily infecting disease.
142 'a 'ur|= {'a re 'u re} described as {'ur sgra da re thug tshoms dang 'a 'ur gyi sgra chen po} a loud sound of ha-hur or a loud whirring noise.
142 byan po|a cook. {byan mo} a housewife, a woman who cooks food; acc. to Sch. a divorced woman; and {byan tshud pa} 'to allure, entice, seduce.'
142 byon pa|SANST v. {'byon pa}; {byon du re nas} SANST; expecting or awaiting his arrival: {bod ston rnams byon du re nas ci mgon mdzad} (A. 86).
142 'chag sa|SANST ({zhabs 'chag sa lta bu}) a place for walking in; {'chag sar 'chag pa} to take a constitutional walk within a limited distance.
142 dga' dgu|SANST intercourse; association; merriment; {dga' dgur spyod pa} SANST to perform conjugal rites; also to indulge in sexual enjoyment.
142 dkor mdzod|is a general name for wealth or property and hence is frequently used to signify {bang mdzod ka} treasury; treasure-chest (Oag. 5).
142 dmag rum|= {mun pa thibs pa} darkness: {khams sum mun pa'i dmag rum sel mdzad pa} the destroyer of the darkness of the three worlds. (Yig. 9).
142 don grub|= {don kun grub} 1. Amoghasiddha, v. {don yod grub pa} post. 2. SANST assemblage. 3. common personal name in use in Tibet and Sikkim.
142 dris pa|v. {'dri ba}. {dris} SANST, SANST asked, an interrogation. {dris nas} SANST having asked; {yang dag dris} well asked; asked carefully.
142 gdos pa|= {mnyan pa} 1. a boat, a ship; {gdos thag} a boat-rope. 2. a mast.\n\nSyn. {rlung g.yor thogs pa}; {gru'i dar po 'dzin pa} (Oag. 38).
142 gnyig tu|SANST; = {gcig tu} into one, aimed at one, having only one object in view; but {gnyig po mdza' 'dug} seems to = the two loved as one.
142 go dam bA|‡ n. of a drug.\n\nSyn. {yangs pa can}; {ri mo can}; {ba glang mig}; {mchog sbyin ma}; {dbang po bkra ba}; {kaM ka chen po} (Moon.).
142 gong 'og|= {ltag 'og} SANST upper and lower; {gzhi gong} folio; {gong sku gzhogs} a title of honour, signifying his highness, excellence, etc.
142 gru kha|or {gru shan kha} or {gru btang sa} landing place on the side of a river, etc.; a ferry. See maps in Survey Report of A. K.'s journey.
142 gsal|1. SANST, SANST separate, SANST, distinct, SANST expressed, {rab gsal} SANST illuminated, fully manifest. 2. for {gsal shing} SANST pale.
142 ka pa la|‡ SANST the skull; the forehead. In Tib. Budh. kapala or kapali signifies either the skull or a drinking cup made of the human skull.
142 'khob ba|+\n= {ngan pa} bad; wicked; low; barbarous; rough; rude; {mtha' 'khob} border; also border country; {yang 'khob} distant border land.
142 khral gsar|levying of new tax: {sngar med pa'i khral gsar bkal nas sde mi ser la sdug po gtang} by levying fresh taxes to oppress the tenants.
142 khra mar|a kind of biscuit made in twisted cross ribs and painted red. These are given only to Government officials at state dinners in Tibet.
142 khyi'u'i khyi'u|khyi phrug or {khyi gu} puppy; pup: {khyi'u'i khyi'u dbyung ba'i tshul du} SANST in the manner of a puppy being brought forth.
142 klu dug|= {grul 'bum zla ba'i nu zho can/_dug ngan pa zhig gi ming /} 1. n. of an indolent poison. 2. n. of a very venomous snake (Sman. 350).
142 kondi na+ya|‡ SANST the son of Upayamati; in Tib. {thabs ldan ma} n. of a Muni or sage; n. of a grammarian; a patronymic of the poet Jayadeva.
142 kri ka lA Sha|‡ SANST a small lizard. There is an account of this animal being once offered as a burnt sacrifice to the gods (K. d. {ya} 214).
142 lhan skyes|or {lhan cig skyes pa} SANST, SANST born together with, as twins; also, esp., {lha} or {'dre} born together with every human being.
142 ma Ni pA tra|‡ SANST pure leaf-gold: {gser ma ni pA tra snyim pa gang phul} presented one handful of pure gold-leaf called mani-patra (A. 37).
142 me na ka|+\nSANST 1. = {lang tsho ma} a maiden, a youthful woman. 2. n. of a celestial courtezan (Yig. k. 37). 3. the daughter of Vrishanasva.
142 mngon du ldang ba|or {langs pa} SANST, SANST getting up; (from one's seat out of respect to another person); removal from a place; going away.
142 nyang ro bsham po mkhar|a small town in Tsang: {nyang ro bsham po mkhar gyi ri rtse la} on the top of the hill of Ñao-ro bsham-po mkhar (Yig).
142 nyen pa|1. = {nyeg thag}, v. {nyag ma}. 2. an enemy. 3. to be pained, pinched, pressed hard, e.g., by hunger; to labour, to drudge, v. {bang}.
142 pho so|one of position; {pho so thon pa} = {mgo thon pa} one who has made himself prominent, distinguished. In W. {pho so can} proud, haughty.
142 rang rgyal|1. = {rangs sangs rgyas}. 2. {rang rgyal gyis 'gro ba} to live after one's own option or pleasure (Sch.). Self-will(ed), obstinacy.
142 ri ka sha|SANST n. of a flower: {ji ltar skams las skyes pa'i me tog gi nang na me tog ri ri ka sha mchog tu gyur pa ltar} (K. my. {kha}, 59).
142 rkang gcig pa|SANST one-footed, met. a tree; the fabulous countries of the Hurao and Tsu-ta, the people of which are said to walk on one foot.
142 rtul bzang skyes|= {rtul can ma'i bu} the son of Rtul-can-ma, one of the ten incarnations of Virnu; a name of SANST; {dga' byed dgra sta can}.
142 sa 'dzin|1. = {sa 'dzin pa} SANST Gandhara, the modern Kandahar; SANST mountain. 2. = {rgyal po} SANST king (Moon.). 3. symb. fig. 7 (Rtsii.).
142 skyed 'phel|yod pas med la bu lon skyed 'phel thong (the rich one) who has should give loan on interest to one who has not (Kathao. {ka} 115).
142 snyan|SANST, SANST, resp. for {rna ba} the ear: {rgyal po'i snyan du thos} it came to the king's hearing. {snyan khung} the ear-hole, hearing.
142 theg pa'i stobs|SANST one of the ten spiritual strengths of a Bodhisattva so called on account of the superiority of doctrine, v. {stobs bcu}.
142 thig nag|SANST 1. one of the eight hot hells where the damned are sawn to pieces, lines being drawn upon them, v. {tsha dmyal}. 2. black spot.
142 ting du ka|‡ SANST n. of one of two trees Diospyros embryopteris or Diospyros glutinosa; a Karsa is said to = the weight of the Tinduka fruit.
142 tre tre ha|(by the context) a dangerous disease of the stomach or a serious symptom of it (Jä.).\n\n(EEE Jäschke actually reads {tre tre ho}.)
142 yig mkhan|one who is versed in the art of reading and writing.\n\nSyn. {yi ge pa}; {bris pa mkhan}; {yi ge'i mkhan po}; {smyu gu can} (Moon.).
142 yu tang|an ancient monastery in Nepal: {bal yul grub pa'i gnas chen po yu tang lhun gyis grub pa'i btsug lag khang chen po} (K. g. {ga}, 191).
142 zla mtshan|SANST, SANST menstruation, monthly course of women; {zla mtshan med pa} SANST one without menses.\n\nSyn. {rdul}; {me tog} (Moon.).
143 bka' sgyur btang ba|to instruct a subordinate in a rough pointed manner, cautioning him against his faults; to counsel against wrong practices.
143 bkod ldan|= {zla ba bcu gcig pa} or {dgun zla 'bring po} the eleventh month of the Tibetan year, sometimes corresponding with January (Rtsii.).
143 brtsam gyur las|work that has been undertaken; {brtsam pa} commencement, an undertaking; {brtsams pa} ({bya ba}) SANST commenced, commencement.

143 dal bon|a sect of the Bon: {dal bon lu gu gar dal khams dang chas pa dang} the Dal-Bon came from the soft regions where the lambs dwell (D.R.).
143 dgang gzar shing|n. of a tree, the tree resembling tiger's feet.\n\nSyn. {stag gi rkang pa}; {tsher ma zhim}; {sa 'tsho}; {tshig mang} (Moon.).
143 dgra sta|SANST an axe the blade of which is semi-circular; a sector-like disk; a weapon of war.\n\nSyn. {sta re}; {dgra sta}; {tho ba} (Moon.).
143 'di tsug yin|in W.: how is this? {'di rang yin} it is he himself: {tshe dang ldan pa 'di tsug yin} how is the venerable monk himself? (A. 132).
143 dpal gos|‡ 1. SANST lotus flower (Moon.). 2. SANST [dwelling with Sri, n. of Virnu]S. {dpal gyi be'us mtshan} another epithet of Virnu (Moon.).
143 'dum bu|seems to indicate the three {se rgod}, {skyed pa}, {'om bu} which also are called {g.yu 'dum}, {gser 'dum}, {mchong 'dum} (Mio-rda. 2).

143 kun tu gzigs|he who sees all things and everywhere by his divine eye of knowledge; n. of a Buddha, also that of the Bodhisattva Avalokitesvara.

143 lcang ma|1. willow, Salix viminalis. 2. a general name for trees that are planted in the vicinity of villages; SANST the ratan, Calamus rotang.
143 ltem pa|the state of being full, e.g., a vessel full of water; full, over flowing; {ltem po} full; {ltem ltem} so full that it runs over (Jä.).

143 phug pa lhun grub rgya mtsho|n. of a celebrated author born in Lhokha. He wrote commentaries on the works of Pad-dkar, Sha-luo, and Gsal sgrom.
143 ram ma|‡ (SANST) country between Tipperah and Arrakan in Burma, the ancient Chittagong. The name survives in the modern small town called Ramu.
143 rgyal byed tshal|SANST n. of the grove which was purchased by Anathpindada a merchant of Sravasti and where the Buddha resided for a long time.
143 rjes dpag|1. SANST conjecture, guessing or guess. 2. consideration, deliberation. 3. acc. to Was. a syllogism consisting of three propositions.
143 shing ka pet tha|‡ (SANST) SANST; the Kapettha tree.\n\nSyn. {ka ped}; {skyur rtsi}; {so nyams byed}; {da dha pha la}; {zho 'bras can} (Moon.).

145 'jam dbyangs|SANST v. {'jam dpal} called also the principal Bodhisattva among {nye ba'i sras chen brgyad} the eight spiritual sons of the Buddha.
145 'jur gegs|n. of a kind of Yi-dag whose throat is so contracted that a drop of water can hardly pass through it to quench his ever-burning thirst.
145 kha mnyam|skad mnyam of equal, i.e., same words or opinion: {lto mnyam zas nas kha mnyam lab pa} (you) eat together (you) should agree in speech.
145 'khor lo dang 'khor lo chen po lha'i me tog|(K. d. {tsha} 368) n. of a celestial flower; idem {tsa kra dang tsa kra chen po}. (K. d. {zha} 156.).
145 lta bas mi ngoms|not satisfied with a glance, i.e., wishing to look at it more; hence = {gzugs mdzes pa} a very handsome shape or person (Moon.).
145 lum bi|‡ lum bi ni SANST n. of a queen, and that of a grove called after her, situated in the Nepal Terai where Buddha is said to have been born.

148 lnga sde bzang po|the five early disciples of Buddha:- Kaundinya, Ashvajit, Varpa, Mahanaman, and Bhadrika, who first received his teachings (Yig.).

148 nya phyis|SANST mother-of-pearl; an oyster shell; it is believed that any food or drink kept in a vessel of mother-of-pearl never becomes poisonous.
148 phra rgyas|= {nyon mongs} SANST misery, because it first comes in insignificant form and then assumes more dangerous shape and important dimensions.
148 rdo dkar|({shel gyi rigs} a kind of crystal) SANST, SANST a white stone, acc. to Sch. alabaster. {rdo dkar po chig thub} a mineral medicine (Moon.).

148 rten khri|= {mchod bshams} a chapel or cabinet to hold images with accommodation for keeping offerings before them and for religious books (Rtsii.).
148 sa bcu'i dbang phyug|SANST; = {byams pa mgon po} an epithet of Maitreya Bodhisattva who has passed through all the ten stages of saintly perfection.
148 seng ge'i khri|SANST a throne so called from its being supported by golden lions. The throne on which Buddha's image is seated borne by eight lions.
148 sgrog gdan|(dog-dao) the triangular patch generally made up of satin on the {pang gdan} i.e., the bib which covers the front of a woman's petticoat.

154 sbo|the upper part of the belly; {sbo tshil} fat from it; {sbo rkun pa} pick-pocket C. (Jä.).\n\n(EEE The original has {sba tshil} for {sbo tshil} above.)
154 sen dha pa|‡ prob. Tibetanized form of the word Siddha = {bsod snyoms pa} a Buddhist monk or mendicant; {se nya ba} and {sen da ba} are its corrupt forms.
154 skrag pa|to be terrified, frightened, afraid of something. This word is nearly always combined with {'jigs pa} as in {'jigs skrag pa}, to be panic-struck.
154 sku brnyan|I: a reflected image, v. {sku 'dra} or {gzugs brnyan} likeness (Moon.).\n\nII: = {sku sha} the health or flesh of a respectable person (Moon.).

157 mkho byed|colloq. kho-che, necessary things; what may be needed: khö-la kho-che yö-pe rik di dir nyo ma chok the kind which you wanted cannot be bought here.
157 mo yig|or {mo yi yi gi} feminine letters (acc. to the Tibetan Grammar) are {ga}, {ja}, {da}, {ba}, {dza}, {wa}, {zha}, {za}, {'a}, {ya}, {sha}, {sa} (Situ.).

157 nu rin|the price of milk; the money-present which a bridegroom has to make to the bride's mother for the trouble she took in suckling her (Sikkim and Ladak).

171 lcig lcig|slightly moving: {'bu srin la sogs pa chang 'gag gi sbang ma bzhin lcag lcig yod pa la/} moving as little worms and insects do, like grain, &c., in fermentation.
171 ma Ni bka' 'bum|‡ n. of a religious work, the authorship of which is attributed to Avalokitesvara by the Rñio-ma sect (J. Zao.). But usually ascribed to Srong-btsan Gampo.
171 mtha' ma|SANST, SANST 1. the end; the outermost or extreme side or thing. 2. border, hem, seam, of dresses. {deng mthong ba mtha' ma} today we see (him) for the last time.
171 nam srod|= {sa sros} the hours of night between 9 and 12 P.M., in India. Acc. to Jä. darkness of night: {nam srod bying song ba'i tshe} as it was almost quite dark (Mil.).
171 ngom|1. n. of a place in Tibet (Deb. {ga} 30). 2. satisfaction: {ngom du rung ba zhig kho bos byed pa yin mod/} I indeed accomplished something very satisfactory (A. 152).
171 'od ldan|1. SANST, SANST, SANST the sun (Moon.). 2. n. of the chief city of the Asura, the city of Rahu (Sorig. 30). 3. SANST, SANST a passionate person, one very lustful.
171 'o ma'i chu zhes bya ba'i rgya mtsho|n. of a fabulous sea the water of which is white like milk, situated beyond the ocean to the north of Rirab or Meru (K. d. {ra}, 293).
171 phug ron|SANST, SANST, SANST a pigeon.\n\nSyn. {skad cig 'dod ldan}; {co co sgrog}; {rdo yi zas can}; {rgya phyibs gnas}; {'cha' dig snyan}; {'phrul ba'i mig can} (Moon.).
171 ra lung|n. of a village two days' journey east from Gyang-tse in Tsang where the Buddhist Saint Hgro mgon Gtsao-pa Rgya ras founded the monastery of Ralûo (Loo. {za}, 28).
171 rdo rje chos kyi glu|hymns of Buddhist Tantrikism: {go so ma pu rir rdo rje chos kyi glu bsgyur te} (A. 66) having translated Tantrik hymns at the monastery of Kusumapuri.
171 re skan|also ordinarily {re kan}, = seldom, by no means, never: {yong re skan} that can seldom happen; {tshim par 'gyur re skan} they can by no means be satisfied with it.
171 rgya mtsho sbas pa|*\nSamudra Gupta; SANST n. of ancient monastery found buried under sand by King Dharmapala, near site of which was founded the monastery of Vikramasila.
171 rgyas byed 'byung po'i lag pa|= {dbang lag} n. of medicinal plant growing below the limit of snow in the Himalayas and resembling the human hand in appearance (Sman. 416).
171 ri dvags sha ra bha|£-\nSANST.\n\nSyn. {gyen mig can}; {seng ge 'joms}; {nags na spyod}; {sha rdul}; {steng rkang can}; {sha ra bha}; {seng ge rkang pa brgyad pa} (Moon.).
171 rkang brgyad pa|a fabulous lion having eight feet. An imaginary lion of Buddhist design with eight legs, generally found in sculpture and in Tibetan mythological pictures.
171 rnam phye|rnam phyed, = {rnam par dbye ba} 1. SANST distinction, division, section: {rnam par phye ste} SANST dividing, having divided or differentiated. 2. = {rnam byed}.
171 rten cing 'brel bar 'byung snying po'i cho ga'i gzungs|SANST n. of a dharani expressing the essence of the doctrine of relative existence or origination (K. gu. {pa} 288).
171 saM su kha|‡ SANST n. of a fabulous region situated beyond the snowy mountains of Sambhala the people of which are hermaphrodites like the Indian Hara-gauri (Lam-yig. 41).
171 se shing|a kind of nettle. Acc. to Cs. a tree or shrub, good for hedges. {se dug} poison contained in {se shing}. {se mog} or {se dug nad} = {reg dug nad} syphilis (Med.).
171 sgrig lad|defect in fixing gems on ornaments: {mu med kyi sgrig lad 'ga' zhig byung 'dug rung} even though there was some defect in fixing a sapphire (Rtsii. and Yig. 17).
171 shing ba glang rmig pa|the bull's eye-flower.\n\nSyn. {kha dog gsum pa}; {bur shing dri}; {tsher ma zhim}; {sa'i tsher ma}; {nags kyi rva rtsi}; {sa'i 'gyur byed} (Moon.).

172 hrang|1. = {thang po} strong, hardy: {rgad po de hrang po 'dug} that old man is hardy. 2. alone, {pho hrang}, {mo hrang} a single man and woman, also = {pho rang} celibate.
172 'jim pa|SANST mud, clay, also muddy water (Moon.). {'jim sku} mud image or statue. {'jim skong} a small cup of clay; a crucible (Cs.). {'jim gzugs} a figure formed of clay.

172 ser khral|fees paid to a Serkyim-pa priest for protection against damage done by hail, i.e., money paid to a Tantrik lama for his preventive ceremonies against hail storms.
172 skyer dman|= {skyes dman} a woman. The former is a corruption of the latter and, sounded kyermen, is one of the most familiar terms in the colloquial for "wife" or "woman."

173 rkyang ma|n. of an artery often referred to in mystic meditation. It is one of the three arteries denominated Srog-rtsa rio-po, and is asserted to run towards the left side.
173 rta bzang lcag bzhin|(lit. as a whip is necessary to keep even a good horse in order) is said to be a common saying Tibet for one person sending his remembrances to another.

173 spyan dmigs|'the object of vision'; any object, mental or visual, which an ascetic employs for the purpose of concentrating his mind in the process of systematic meditation.

174 gyod gzhi|= {'khrug pa'i rtsa ba} the basic or grounds of a quarrel or fight: {tha ma chags sdang gi gyod gzhi} the last is the ground of contention between lust and passion.
174 ja shing|tea-plant. In Tibet the tea-plant is styled {rgya nad sel shing} i.e., the plant which cures Indian or Chinese diseases, as being an antidote against malarial fever.

174 klu ldog|the retiring of the Lu to their abodes in the nether regions is called {klu ldog}, which time is generally calculated by the Tibetan astrologers to fall in December.
174 kod|boiled: {ja de kod nas ka ra bram po lnga byin pas jo bo dgyes} (A. 95) the tea having been boiled (prepared) and given with five lumps of sugar, the Jo-wo was gratified.
174 ko re|or {ko ra} cup for drinking; {shing kor} wooden cup which every Tibetan carries with him in the pocket of his great coat next to his bosom; {shel kor} a drinking glass.
174 ko tse|ja brgyad pa the Chinese name for the brick-tea used by the common people of Tibet. It is called {ja brgyad pa} the eighth or the inferior quality of tea (S. kar. 80).

174 lha ma srin|gods, Asura, and Rakrasa, etc.; or, perhaps, also {lha ma srin sde brgyad} the eight classes of gods, Asura, Rakrasa, etc. i.e., the whole world of spirits (Jä.).

174 'phags 'khrungs|the birth place of the venerable ones; SANST the Buddhist name of India.\n\nSyn. {rgya gar yul}; {yul dbus}; {bsod nams sa gzhi}; {dbus 'gyur 'chang} (Moon.).

178 chos 'khor rgyal|n. of the place where the first Dalai Lama was born, and where there is a large monastery which is generally visited once by the successive Grand Lamas of Lhasa.
178 dal yams|= {nad rims ngan pa} a pestilence of the worst kind, with the following symptoms:- {gzer thung}; {khrag nad}; {ltag 'gyel}; {cog 'gyel}; {mkhris rims}; etc. (Sman. 119).
178 'dod pa'i 'khri shing|an epithet of the wife of Kamadeva.\n\n(EEE The original gives the transliteration of the headword as hdod-pahi khri-shio which is clearly a dropout error.)
178 do mod|= {'phral du} 1. quickly; {do mod ting nge 'dzin gsal ba'i dkyil 'khor dam pa ru} (place) quickly in the holy mandala of unsullied contemplation. 2. today, this day (Cs.).
178 dpa' bo'i 'dug stangs|the manner of sitting of a lha or minor god (Ya-sel.).\n\n(EEE The original gives the transliteration of the headword as "dpah-pohi-..." which is in error.)
178 'dre rje badzra|‰-\n({khyung po rdo rje}) n. of a celebrated physician of Tibet who was born of the family of Byu-thog-pa. He was physician to king Guo-sroo guo-btsao. (Gyu. 2.).
178 gseng yab|balcony. {khyod kyis kun dga' ra ba gseng yab dang mthong rgya che ba 'di'i nang du} in this garden house with its excellent balcony and wide view you should (rejoice).
178 gshin rje'i sring mo|({chu bo ya mu nA}) the sister of the lord of death; an epithet of the river Yamuna.\n\n(EEE The original has "({chu bo ya mu na})" above which is in error.)
178 gsung gin|saying, talking about, reciting, reading or preaching: {gsang sngags rgyud sde gsung gin yod pa na} (A. 13) when he was reading the Tantra class of Buddhist scriptures.
178 gtam rgyud|SANST oral tradition, legend: {de'i gtam rgyud} the legend of him; {byis pa na re gtam rgyud du bshad dam} the boy said, has it been described in history? (Hbrom. 54).
178 gung du byed pa|to divide through middle; to dissect anatomically; {dbyar gyi gung la} in the middle of summer; {nam gyi gung la} at the midnight hour; the middle watch of night.
178 gyang rim|pisè layer or one layer of pisé, i.e., as much as is stamped in at a time, about one ell in height; this frequently serves for a measure of the depth of the snow (Jä.).
178 hab sha che|a dispute, a quarrel. {snying rje med pa'i stobs kyi hab sha che ba dang} quarrel with merciless violence (A. 144). {hab sha byed pa} in Mil., to dispute, to quarrel.
178 khang pa g.yo|SANST the roof of a house: {khang pa g.yo ba} to cover a house, to roof it; {khang pa ral zhing grum pa} or {'drums pa} SANST a delapidated house; a ruined edifice.
178 kha skong|SANST, SANST, a mouthful; completion; appendix of a book: {kha skong ba} 1. to fill up a void; to make up a deficiency. 2. to fill up the mouth with water, to rinse it.
178 khro 'joms pa|to suppress anger or wrath: {gang zhig bsgrims te khro 'joms pa/_de ni 'di dang gzhan du bde} (Spyod.) he who can subdue his anger will be happy here and hereafter.
178 kru kru tris|+\n(tu-tu ti) SANST a kind of yellow chintz resembling satin of great value, formerly highly prized in India and Tibet. It is called {grung thang rgya ser gos chen}.
178 mi gtsang ba|SANST, SANST human flesh, ordure; remnants of food fit to be thrown away. {mi gtsang gi mchod sbyin} SANST a sacrifice in which human beings may even be slaughtered.
178 ngag dbang ye shes rgya mtsho|the Lama who with the help of Lhabzao, King of the country round lake Kökönor, conducted the Government of Tibet for thirteen years (Loo. {'a}, 16).
178 nyag gcig|= {kho na} alone, the only: {skyabs kyi nyag gcig dkon mchog gtso} the only refuge is (in) Dkon-mchog gtso (Hbrom. {kha} 28): {sangs rgyas nyag gcig} only Buddha (Jä.).
178 rgyal rnga|SANST drum of victory: {rgyal rnga rab 'byams zhing kun khyab par bsgrags} the drum of victory diffusing far and wide proclaims your fame all over the world (Yig. k.).
178 rgya mtsho dga'|SANST the moon; {rgya mtsho'i zla} SANST reflection of the moon in the ocean; {rgya mtsho pa 'am mchod gyi dpyad} SANST a seaman or anything belonging to the sea.
178 ri bo che|n. of place with a famous monastery on the Ngul Chhu in Khams (Loo. {za}, 28). Visited by Capt. Bower and Dr. Thorold on their adventurous journey across Tibet in 1893.
178 rjes thob pa|1. cessation of meditation to take food, but no more of it than is absolutely necessary for preservation of life. 2. SANST, SANST profit, gain. 3. to find the track.
178 rlung gi gshog pa can|(lit. having wind wings) a term for the swiftest horse; the kind of horse to which this compliment is given in Tibet is generally called {gyi ling} (Moon.).

178 rnam gling|or {rnam rgyal gling} 1. n. of a monastery in the town of {rnam gling rdzong} in the Shang district of the province of Tsang (Rtsii.). 2. n. of a Bon work (G. Bon. 4).
178 rnam par rig pa|= {rnam par shes pa} idea, notion; often = SANST [principle]S.; also SANST [knowledge]S. {rnam rig tu bkral pa} 'explained in the sense of the idealists' (Schf.).
178 sgar|defined as {gur mang po phub nas bsdad pa} pitching many tents (at a place); camp; encampment; {dmag sgar} a military encampment; {sgar 'debs pa} to encamp; to pitch a camp.
178 sim pa|= {bde ba} 1. to refresh, to be refreshed; acc. to Jä.: good health, prosperity, or vb. to be well, to be well of. {sims par} adv. = {bde bar} happily, contentedly (Yig.).

179 bu 'khrid|(puti) a common title generally given by parents in Tibet to the first born daughter with a hope that she would bring in the train of birth a {bu} or son to her parents.

181 chu srin rdo rje ri mo'i bran mo|a goddess who rules over the forest of Kong-po and is believed to possess the power of stopping at will the course of the great river Yeru Tsang-po.
181 ci bde ba|SANST 1. what is well, good; what pleases; as it pleases them; as they like. 2. name of a section of Tantrik Buddhists in the monastery of Vikramasila during Atisa's time.
181 ci 'dod pa|SANST whatever one wishes; as much as desired; whatever (they) wish; {ci 'dod pa bzhin thob pa} to get according to what one wished [an attribute of a Bodhisattva (M.V.)]
181 cog bu pa|1. one who lives in a lonely mountain cavern or in a small tent that accommodates but one man. 2. [SANST sitting and not lying down; one of the twelve ascetic practices]S.
181 dar ma|I: Dar-ma n. of a district in the province of Hphan-yul, with a small fort (Rtsii.).\n\nII: SANST, SANST, SANST, also SANST, middle age (in man or woman) after the 40th year.
181 dbang bskur ri|also called {dga' ldan dbang bskur ri} a hill east of Lhasa so styled because king {srong btsan sgam po} was consecrated with water obtained therefrom (Loo. {'a}, 5).
181 dum pa|1. SANST some: {dum pa ste} it being a little, somewhat. 2. a division, or volume, in the dialect of Amdo: {'bum dum pa bcu gnyis} the twelve volumes of the Bum (scriptures).
181 dza hu'i bu mo|‡ SANST an epithet of the Ganges {phebs tshogs kyang dza hu'i bu mo'i rgyan bzhin stsol ba khyen khyen/} pray let your letters come to me like the flow of the Ganges.
181 glum|or {sbang glum} fresh fermented rice, barley, or wheat, used instead of malt in brewing beer. {chang btsos phab btab bsnyal nas langs pa chang gi glum mam sbang glum yang zer}.
181 g.yul bzlog pa|to avert war, also, to rout an enemy, to make the enemy run away or retire: {g.yul bzlog pa'i 'khor lo} a wheel which can subdue an enemy and bring victory (Gyu. 10).
181 i khug|= {ag} in W. hiccough, sob (Jä.).\n\n(EEE The text is cut off in all available original editions (page 1,349), and the "s" in "sob" is conjectural though of correct meaning.)
181 in dra nI la|‡ sapphire.\n\nSyn. {mthon ka che}; {an da snyil}; {dbang sngon}; {nor bu'i snying po}; {nor bu sngon po}; {ka ka nI la}; {nI la}; {sngo skya nI la}; {tsha li} (Moon.).
181 ka lan dza ri ka|‡ SANST 1. a flowering plant; also the flower use in yajña—sacrificial fire (K. g. {da} 33). 2. belonging to SANST, an animal struck with a poisoned arrow; tobacco.
181 kha dkar po|= {snang ba gsal} 1. bright: {bkra shis pa}. 2. auspicious; of happy omen; agreeable; pleasant looking; {kha dkar gting nag} outside white inside black, i.e., plausible.
181 ko la|a grub which breeds in hides; a kind of hide-moth; {ko la mug ma sha'i 'bu 'dzi shig shig gi rigs lta bu/} the Kola moth, something like a species of vermin in flesh (Rtsii.).
181 ko lpags|hide; also tanned skin; {ko lpags kyi gzhi} SANST hide or leather material or stuff included in the fourteen materials prescribed for clothing to be used by Buddhist monks.
181 mkhrig ma|(thig-ma) the wrist of the hand (Jä.); the part of the hand which (in women) is adorned with bangles. It is also called {nor bu 'ching ba} the part where jewels are bound.
181 mngal|SANST, resp. {lhums} SANST, SANST the uterus; the womb; also the side of the breast, whence Buddhas are generally born lest they be contaminated by the impurities of the womb.
181 myos|SANST, SANST, SANST excitement, loss of control, sensual intoxication [a kind of grass, Poa cynosuroides; the wood of the Ficus religiosa used for kindling fire by attrition]S.
181 ngom pa|pf. {ngoms pa} SANST, SANST; {nor ngoms lta bu} to satisfy one's self with gain; to be contented: {ma ngoms} I am not satisfied; {ngoms tshad 'thung ba} to drink one's fill.
181 nyang tsi brag|a kind of yellow fibrous root largely exported from Tibet to China: {nyang rtsi brag nyag re re 'bru} a ñag "weight of ñao-tsi-brag is so much a piece, &c." (Rtsii.).
181 pad ma'i skyil krung|SANST ({lha rnams kyi bzhugs tshul}) the manner of sitting of the gods (Ya-sel.); and so, too, that adopted by a lama sitting {mtshams la}, i.e., in meditation.
181 phru ma|+\n1. the womb; also explained as meaning: {phru ma gson por lpags pa bshu ba lta bu} (Khrid. 46). 2. = {pho brang} a palace, castle; also = {dmag sgar} military encampment.
181 rkyan|1. a brass vessel like a tea-pot, with a spout; in W. "o-kyan," a milk-pot. 2. pot-belly; paunch (Sch.); {chab rkyan} a vessel for water; {chang rkyan} a vessel for wine (Jä).
181 rnam smin|or {rnam par smin pa} SANST, SANST lit. fully ripened, become mature. In Budh. the fullness of one's sin. {sdig pa'i rnam par smin pa} to suffer the effects of one's sins.
181 rnying ba|vb., pf. {brnyings} to age, wax old; {gos brnyings} worn clothes; {lham brnyings} old shoes; {rnying bar 'gyur ba}, {rnying bar byed pa} to wear out in a short time (Jä.).
181 sgral ba|(dal-wa) 1. to cut into small pieces, viz., the picture of an enemy whom one wishes to destroy (Jä.). 2. {chu sogs las sgral ba} to pass over or travel upon a river or sea.
181 sgres pa|(deh-pa) n. of a numeral figure used in Buddhist astrology: {sgreg pa shin tu brtan pa'o zhes bshad de 'di la grangs gnas brgya dang nyer brgyad 'byung zhing} (Ya-sel. 57).
181 sgro phug pa|n. of a celebrated Nyingma Lama who lived in Dophug: {sgro ston gyi lha khang sgro phug tu brtsigs pa lags so/} the temple of Do-ton was built at Do-phug (Deb. {ga} 6).
181 sgrun pa|+\n(dun-pa), pf. and fut. {bsgrun} SANST 1. to resound; to reply in the same tone; to rival. 2. to compare; to emulate, vie, contend with (Cs.).\n\nSyn. {'gran pa} (Moon.).
181 shing gzong|SANST an implement that "eats up" wood, or bores in wood, a gimlet [1. a carpenter's chisel or adze. 2. the Indian fig tree]S.\n\nSyn. {shing za}; {shing 'bigs} (Moon.).
181 snyun rmed|+\n({snyun} illness, {rmed} = {dri ba}) to inquire, to inquire after one's health: {jo bo la snyun rmed}, {'di skad mdzad de} (A. 75) thus inquiring if the lord was well.
181 stong 'khor lo|1. a wheel with a thousand spokes (of fabulous properties). 2. {stong 'khor zhabs drung} n. of an incarnate Lama of the monastery of Stoo-hkhor near Koko Nor in Amdo.
181 the le le|evil-hearted, vicious: {la la na re kong tse 'phrul gyi rgyal po mna' zan po the le le zer} some said that the miraculous king Kong-tse was blasphemous and vicious (D.R.).
182 a 'bras|n. of a kind of fruit in appearance like the bulbous excrescence of the maple tree: {a 'bras mkhal ma'i nad la mchog tu phan} the fruit a-dé is very useful in kidney disease.
182 be chon|SANST, SANST (Zam. 3) club with an ornamental hammer, knob, dorje, or human head-like figure on its top which the gods generally carry in their hands to fight with the Asura.
182 bkram pa|pf. {bkrams pa}, a form of {'grem pa} SANST, SANST, SANST to spread over, scatter.\n\nSyn. {dgram pa}; {brdal pa sha} also {gtor ba}; {'thord pa} SANST; {gtsugs pa} (Moon.).

182 chu bur|= {chu'i lbu ba} SANST (Moon.) 1. bubbles of water, also froth. 2. watery eruptions on the skin, vesicles, blister, occasioned by a burn. 3. acc. to Jä. boil, ulcer, abscess.
182 gter chen po'i bum pa|n. of one of the eight auspicious symbols of the Northern Buddhists,—the pot of treasure, i.e., the wishing-pot which yields whatever precious object is sought.
182 gu zul|(for {ral gu zul ma}) hair-pendants of precious stones of women in Tibet: {mo rang gi ral gu zul phud nas phul} taking off her hair-ornaments, she offered them (A. {ka} 102.).
182 g.yu drug sngon mo|= {'brug} the dragon symbolical of the thunder; and hence signifying thunder: {dgung thon mo'i g.yu 'brug sngon mo 'di gzugs med kyang stong gsum skad kyis gang /}
182 ka na tsa|‡ (prob. SANST) lit. sprouting; generic name for a tree; the plant Abrus precatorius; {shing ka na tsa'i me tog rnams/} the flowers of the ka-na-tsa tree (K. g. {tha} 227).
182 kho re|1. in Khams an expression of displeasure or anger towards a man: {a rogs} Oh friend! is the opposite of {kho re}. 2. one of the early kings of Tibet, son of king Lde-cug mgon.
182 khu ba kun ldan|= {spos dkar shing} the Sal tree, the dried sap of which is used as incense.\n\nSyn. {sA la'i shing}; {sra rtsi shing}; {spos dkar shing}; {mchod sbyin spos} (Moon.).
182 lo 'dod|= {'dod lo} or {'dod pa tsam} yearning: {lo 'dod dang re ltos gang yang mi bdog pas} (Hbrom. {kha}, 13) he had neither yearning nor hopes whatever, the earthly-minded sinner.
182 lo tog|or {lo thog} SANST the produce of the year, the harvest, crop; {lo tog rnga ba} to reap it, to gather it in. {lo tog mchog tu bde ba} = {spos dkar shing} the Sal tree (Moon.).
182 ma gzhi|= {don gyi rtsa ba} subject matter: {ma gzhi de gang nas byung} whence has that subject matter arisen? {ma gzhi'i thad} having regard to the chief subject, or subject matter.
182 mchin nan|lit. liver-pressing, i.e., keeping the liver in order. {mchin nan byed pa} to breakfast. It is believed that taking food early in the morning keeps the liver in good order.
182 me mgal|1. fire brand: {me mgal gyi 'khor lo} the circle made by a fire brand when quickly swung round 2. half burnt fire-wood, a piece of wood which has been partly burnt (Oag. 15).

182 ngo srungs|1. regard to the opinion of others; an aiming at applause. 2. body-guard: {nga la dpon med g.yog med ngo bsrung med} I have no master, no servant, none to guard me (A. 7).

182 rnam 'phyo|as met. fish. {rnam 'phyo'i bdag po} the king of fish, who is possessed of a thousand teeth. Syn. {nya yi rgyal po}; {mche ba stong lda}; {so mang ba}; {khri can} (Moon.).
182 rna theg can|on who can hear patiently; {bzod pa sgom pa'i rna theg can} one that is able to listen to all with patience; particularly one who is meditating on the merit of patience.
182 rngab pa|1. to be hungry: {bkres rngab pa} to be greedy; to have a craving appetite; acc. Jä. 2. cf. {rngam pa} to crave; to desire earnestly. 3. in W. colloq. for {rnga ba}, to mow.
182 rtag par 'dzin pa|to look upon what is transitory as lasting, and hence to be worldly-minded, a worldling; {nyal ba la rtag pa} steady in lying down, i.e., to be continually at rest.
182 ru leb|'flat-horn,' occurs in {sha ba ru leb} the Cervus Wallichii, and in {'brog gi ru leb} the stag discovered in Central Tibet by Dr. Thorold and afterwards named Cervus Thoroldi.
182 skor lam|a roundabout way; the way or passage round any sacred place, temple or town for pilgrims to circumambulate it; the pathway round about a monastery used for holy processions.

183 ga re|1. in Lhasa very com. colloq. form for "what," sounded káre. 2. where, whence: {ga re 'di 'dra a kyang rang drag byung /} whence comes this oppression, over-powering (Rdsa. 10).
183 glud|a thing given as a ransom; {srog gi glud} a ransom for life: {kho'i glud du lug brgya gsod} slaughter a hundred sheep as a ransom for him, {glud la btang} to ransom a scape-goat.

183 hur|1. has been explained as {bya byi'u'i gshegs sgra lta bu}. 2. {hur hur} to stare at out of wonder or surprise, an expression of amazement: {gcig mig cig la hur hur bltas} (Rdsa.).
183 kur ti|to hasten; {kur ti langs 'gro} to start or go off on any business; (in colloq. language) to start on an errand or mission early in the morning without having even a cup of tea.

183 rnam 'dud|SANST n. of one of the seven golden mountains of the Buddhist cosmography which are situated round Meru (Glr.). It is so called from its crest being slightly bent (So-rig.).

183 rngams|= {dpangs} height or depth; {rngams su} in height or depth; {chu dkyil rngams su dpag tshad 'bum phrag brgyad/} (Yig.) the depth at the middle of the waters was 800,000 yojana.
183 rung chu|water for washing the mouth (of a monk) before taking food and after he has finished his meal: {tha na byan len dang dge rung chu yan chad ma 'dres par 'byed mkhyen} (A. 35).
183 sA lu ljang pa'i mdo|n. of a Sutra in which the twelve Nidanas (conditions of cyclic existence) have been illustrated from the growth of Salu rice and its seedlings (K. d. {ma}, 190).
183 shar kha|n. of a place in Tibet. {shar kha dpon po} the chief or ruler of Shar-kha; also name of a celebrated Lama of that place who was known by the name Pandan Shar kha-wa (Yig. 3).
183 sho sa|also called {sho mo sa} a kind of bean the leaves of which are cooked with Tibetan gruel to add flavour to it; {sho sa dang nas 'dra} and barley are alike (in price). (Rtsii.).
183 sku zhabs|lit. "your honour's feet," is the correct form of the colloq. expression {sku shogs}, meaning your honour, your lordship, your worship. It is generally pronounced as ku-sho.
183 sme khab|prob. an incorrect spelling of {sman khebs} an under-garment worn by Buddhist nuns so that their religious robes may not be defiled by menstrual discharges (K. d. {da}, 424).
183 sos|1. instr. of {so}: {sos btab pa} to bite (Sch.), also to back-bite, to culumniate. 2. a pf. form of {gso ba}: {na sos pa} disease cured; {nyams pa sos pa} cured impaired (health).
183 thang ju|n. of one the emperors of China of the great T'ang dynasty. {thang the jung} emperor T'aijung whose daughter was married to King {srong btsan sgam po} about the year 633 A.D.
183 thun bzhi'i rnal 'byor|an ascetic who meditates or keeps the mind abstracted from worldly objects, &c., continuously during the four watches of the day; the meditation of a whole day.
183 tshogs drug rang grol|a celebrated lama of Amdo ordinarily known by his second name Lama Shabkar, and believed to be an incarnation of Milaraspa. His incarnation still exists in Amdo.
183 'ud|1. ({skad cha chen po lab pa}) swaggering, bragging, bombast, fustian (Cs.); {'ud cher smra ba} to swagger, brag. 2. = {yud} a moment: {'ud kyis} in a moment, instantly, suddenly.

184 'grel pa|1. = {'tshol pa} SANST, SANST to beg, supplicate. 2. to put in, arrange; {tshig don 'grel pa} the arranging or paraphrasing the meanings of words. 3. to explain, comment upon.
184 gtsang ma|SANST, SANST pure, clean; sanctified, celestial: {gtsang ma byung} SANST it has become clean and pure. In colloq. tsangma is the com. word for "clean," opp. to tsog-pa dirty.

184 nges 'gro|transmigration; {nges par 'gro ngan song mtho ris dag zhing sogs su/} return to another state of existence after death, either to hell or heaven, or to any non-earthly place.

184 shor ba|to be fled, to be lost, to escape, slip. {bros shor ba} run away; {rkun ma jag pa la shor ba} taken away by thieves or robbers; {bu lon la shor ba} lost in consequence of debt.
184 srog rlung|SANST, SANST life, life-breath. {srog rlung 'joms pa'i rdo rje gsum} the three precious articles keeping in the life-wind are {shing kun}, {tang kun}, {kha ru tsha} (Sman.).
184 ste'u ka ma|SANST a kind of missile. {ste'u stag} SANST a sharp arrow, v. {ste po}.\n\n(EEE The original has "a searp arrow," which is undoubtedly a typographical error for the above.)
184 sug rmel|‡ or {sug smel} 1. Cs.: a kind of spice. 2. = SANST cardamom: {sug smel mkhal nad grang ba la lus sel} Med.\n\nSyn. {'thum gsum pa}; {lus ngan ma}; {nye ba'i lde mig} (Moon.).
184 thang du|1. in the opinion of; {cung zad dag pa'i re ba yod kyang la la'i thang du} although little reliable hope remained, yet in the opinion of some (J. Zao.). 2. for {thang yig tu}.
184 the se|a king of the {sa bdag} demi-gods residing in the nether regions. {the khyim} n. of his principal wife. {the se grum bu} one of the minor chiefs of {sa bdag} demi-gods (Rtsii.).
184 za grogs|a woman; (in the dialect of Amdo called {'dug grogs}) wife, mistress: {skyid tshe'i za grogs de spangs pa min} the mistress of happier days should not be forsaken (Khrid. 51).
185 bcug pa|pf. of {'jug pa} with, also, the special meanings of; to meddle; to interfere: {nged kyi don la khyod lag bcug don med/} you have no business to interfere in my affairs (Rdsa.).
185 bem chag|= {dkar chag} list of contents: {rgyal rabs kyi bem chag tu 'byung bas de dag tu blta bar} should refer to those occurring in the list of contents of the Rgyalrab (Hbrom. 251).
185 bsten|yongs su nye bar bsten to attend, wait upon respectfully, to serve; SANST lit. being ranged quite closely together, quite huddled together; also sticking most closely (A.K 111-3).
185 byi ba|= {rtsi rtsi} SANST, SANST rat, mouse.\n\nSyn. {rkun mo}; {'bigs byed}; {pri Sha'i mig}; {rko byed}; {bug pa byed}; {ri brag la gnas pa}; {shing gi byi ba}; {dri ma can} (Moon.).
185 chu tshags|SANST 1. a strainer, sieve. 2. n. of a demi-god of the nether world. {chu tshags kyis rung ba} SANST; a monk permitted to use filtered water, i.e., fit to use filtered water.
185 dkar rtsis|or {skar rtsis} astrology: {rgya gar nas bod du dar ba'i rtsis la dkar rtsis zer/} the system of reckoning introduced in Tibet from India is called {dkar rtsis} (D. Shel. 8).
185 dung nge|defined as {'dod pa} or {dad pa mngon sum skyes pa} the growth of real attachment or regard; also {sems dung nge} or {yid dung nge} id. {dung nge ba} constant, continual (Jä.).
185 gcong skad|1. a low fine musical note or voice. 2. cry of sorrow, lamentations, wailing (Oag.).\n\nSyn. {cho nge}; {ye ge bral}; {ma la}; {nyer skad}; {zer zer skad}; {ngud mo} (Moon.).
185 gnas bzod|= {sems bde pa} contentment, easiness at heart. {de bas nged gnyis gnas bzod gang bder 'gro} for that reason let us both with a heart full of ease go to a happy place (Rdsa.).
185 gtsugs pa|1. = {bkam pa} to plant, {sa la gtsugs pa} to put in the ground; {lo tog sogs gtsugs pa} to plant crops (Oag. 56). 2. to bore out, scoop out, excavate (Sch.). 3. = {bkram pa}.
185 g.ya' shing|the maple.\n\nSyn. {bdag sbad}; {mi gsal}; {a dhya NDa}; {skyes ma}; {rab tu char 'bebs ma}; {drang srong brjod}; {shi mbi rtse}; (SANST, SANST); {nags kyi mi 'dra} (Moon.).
185 klad bzo|the making of the outer side of anything: {klad bzo sbug ther skabs dang bstun par bya/} this outer covering and the flannel within must be made to fit in their size (Yig. 22).
185 lag pa Na|or {lak sa Na} SANST; = Lakrmana brother of Rama the hero of the Ramayana.\n\nSyn. {mtshon byed}; {mdzod 'dzin}; {sprin dgra rgyal}; {bshes gnyen bzang}; {mdzod ldan} (Moon.).
185 lcags kyi phung po zhes bya ba'i ri|a fabulous mountain which extends eastward over a distance of 12,000 miles from the ocean and is filled with iron ore and iron-dust (K. d. {ra} 341).
185 legs bshad|elegant description or writings; moral lessons. Cognate terms:- {tshig bzang} elegant saying; {dge ba'i gtam} moral maxims; {snyan ngag ro ldan} also a humorous poem (Moon.).
185 lus chen|1. = as met. {rnga mong} camel (Moon.). 2. epithet of the planet Rahu: {lus chen po'i nang na lha ma yin gyi rgyal po sgra gcan 'dzin mchog tu gyur pa ltar} (K. my. {kha}, 59).
185 mchan|1. a footnote, v. {mchan bu}. 2. SANST the side of the breast; {mchan gyi bu} bosom-child, darling; {mchan gyi mchis brang} bosom-wife; {mchan du 'jug pa} to put into one's bosom.
185 mig ldan|1. = {mkhas pa} or {shes rab can} a learned man, a wise man (Moon.). 2. = {phur bu} (Moon.). 3. = {mig can} a needle. {mig ldan ma} SANST [endowed with the faculty of seeing]S.
185 myags pa|= {rul ba} putrid, decomposed; to cause putrification; Sch. has {myag pa} to chew, pf. {myags}. {myags par byed pa} = {myag pa}; {rul can myags pa} decomposed, putrified (Jä.).
185 nag pa|SANST ({skar ma}) the thirteenth constellation. {nag zla ba} SANST [March-April]S. {nag pas nya} SANST [the full-moon day of March-April]S. {nag pa'i tshogs} [SANST variegated]S.
185 pha mes|SANST 1. paternal ancestors: {pha mes shi ba'i don du} for the defunct ancestors (Vai. so.); {pha mes skabs} SANST of the time of one's ancestors. 2. ({so ma}) SANST [eternal]S.
185 phyogs med|impartial; without country; a vagabond: {gnas nges med du pandi ta phyogs med du byed pa zhig yin zer} he is said to be a stranger Pandit who has no fixed residence (A. 134).
185 pi rto pa|‡ SANST; n. of an Indian Buddhist who is said to have visited Sambhala (K. dun. 47).\n\n(EEE The original gives the transliteration of the headword as "pi-to-pa", {pi to pa}.)
185 rdo 'phangs pa'i mdo|n. of a sutra in the Mdo section of the Kahgyur {ra} 426 describing the miraculous feat of Buddha in throwing missiles performed by him in the country of the Malla.
185 rgyun gtan|= {dus rgyun} at all times; the stream of time: {rgyu gtan gzhung don yin nges rnams} real business; transactions of a public character must always be reliable. (D. Shel. 7).
185 rlung gi bang yod pa zhes bya ba'i bya|a fabulous bird which can fly one thousand miles in a moment and is said to live in the forest called {grib ma sngon po'i nags} (K. d. {ra}, 297).
185 shing shun|SANST, SANST the bark of trees: perhaps, cinnamon. {shing shun gyi chang} wine extracted from the bark of a tree, cinnamon wine.\n\nSyn. {shing lpags}; {shing skogs} (Moon.).
185 skad ngar|rough language: {skad ngar zer bas yul de'i ming yang nga ra thang du btags/} on account of their speaking rough speech the name of that place was called Oa-ra thao (Yig. 65).
185 skyang nul|+\n= {rnyong} or {byug pa} SANST plaster; also pavement; clay-four; mud-flour; {skyang nul byed pa} = {zhal ba byed pa} to pave; to plaster; according to Sch. to rub, polish.
185 skye ba rig pa|inherited intelligence: {khams thams cad 'byung ba lngar shes pas skye pa rig pa} that all the elements from which we spring are known to be five is hereditary knowledge.
185 so le sdong|to remain or appear fresh, fresh looking; {de la me tog shar nas zhag bdun du so le sdod pa} there (in that) blossoms appearing which remained fresh for seven days (A. 107).
185 srid zhu|= {sri zhu} SANST also {bkur sti} praise [service]S. {rten ci yod rnams srid zhu dang ldan par bzhugs su gsol} I pray whatever idols there are may be worshipped ({sgrol ma} 4).
185 ta ru ka|‡ SANST or more properly {tu ru ka} Turkistan: {zer gcig gis mtha' ta ru ka'i pho brang la phog pas} (A. 19) one of the rays at length having fallen on the palace of Turkistan.
185 thams cad sgrol|SANST 1. a general epithet of Buddha, lit. the deliverer of the universe. 2. Visvantara, name of a prince believed to have been Buddha Gautama in his last-but-one birth.
185 thod chags|= {tho yi nang la 'khod pa} entered into the list; registered: {rdzong sdod bsam pa che bas thor chags} the resident official of a Jong generously put into the list (Rtsii.).
185 ting ting ma|n. of a small bird: {byi'u mchu ring ma dang ting ting ma zer ba gnyis 'dug pas/} there were two small birds, one called mchu-rio-ma (the long-beak) and another tio-tio-ma.
185 tshur mo|or {mtshur mo} SANST, paint, pigment: {nag tshur} black-pigment; a mineral found for instance in Nubra used for dying black; {ser tshur} yellow-pigment, {dmar tshur} red-paint.
185 ya man ta ka|‡ 1. SANST the transliterated Sanskrit epithet of Shinje the lord of death. 2. discrepancy in expression or statements. 3. a term expressive of wonder in the Sikk. dialect.
185 zhes|= so thus: {zhes bya ba} so to be styled. {zhes pa} = also thus: {zhes pa brjod nas} having so or thus said. {zhes mtshungs} similarity in appearance, shape, or colour (Rtsii. 40).
186 ba glang ldan|n. of a Yakrini of Rohita who, having invited Buddha with his followers to her place, in honour of this visit caused 500 vihara to be built miraculously (K. du. {pa}, 298).
186 brlan pa|1. another form of {rlon pa}, = {gsher pa} or {sbang ba}: {chus brlan to} (Situ. 76); {brlan sgyes} met. a tree. 2. = {bsdus pa} or {phyogs su gtogs pa} to collect or put aside.
186 'chi med mdzod|SANST n. of a Sanskrit Dictionary composed by Amara Sioha.\n\n(EEE Original has Simha with a dot over the m, but Sioha is the correct Sanskrit transliteration for "lion".)
186 dal du phangs pa|fig. to work or to study assiduously; not to be lazy or indolent: {'o na dal du phangs rig pa slobs zer} he said: but then learn some science not to remain idle (A. 32).
186 dpa' khri gzigs|the first Tibetan who entered monastic life by renouncing the world when the order of Bhikshu was introduced into Tibet under king {khri sring lde'u btsan} (So-rig. 117).
186 gu yangs po|= {dogs po med pa} spacious; capacious: {sa cha gu yangs pa} a spacious, wide place: {sdod sa gu yangs pa} a commodious residence: {sems gu yangs pa} a broad, generous heart.
186 ka la bu|‡ SANST n. of a king; {de'i tshe na rgyal po ka la bu zhes bya ba khro zhing gtum pa/} at that time (there lived) a king named Kalaputra, fierce and wrathful. (K. my. {ka} 209).
186 ka ra da|‡ n. of a bird the cry of which is like the sound of a drum. It is described in Buddhist books as like fire in colour, and as located in the abodes of the Asura (K. d. {'a} 15).
186 'khor gsum|man, horse and cow: {chibs las gzhol te 'khor gsum drung du phul}, alighting from his horse, he presented the three objects, viz., a servant, a horse, and a cow to him (A. 7).
186 khye'u mthon pa|khye'u mthon pa, {khye'u bye ba} the delivery of a child; child-birth. In Kahgyur and Tangyur {khye'u btsas pa} khyehu mtsas-pa = {bu skyes pa} the birth of a male child.
186 khyim bdag dpal sbyin|khyim bdag dpal sbyin zhes pa ni bcom ldan 'das kyi dus su byung ba'i khyim bdag zhig gi ming SANST n. of a householder who was devoted to Buddha (K. ko. {ca} 335).
186 kun la khyab byed ser po|SANST = {ghi wang} (Sman. 107) a bright yellow pigment prepared from the urine or bile of a cow, or vomited in the shape of scidulæ by that animal; bezoar stone.
186 lag nya|= {byin len ma byas par len pa} receipt of a thing without acknowledgement; {ster mkhan med par len pa} to take what is not given, hence {lag nya} sbst.: a grasp, a snatch (Jä.).
186 nyi ma'i gur khang|the sun's pavilion, the halo of five different colours which surrounds the sun; {nyi ma'i lding khang} the floating castle of the sun; {nyi ma'i khyim} the sun-sphere.
186 nying sha|+\none's own flesh; the expression {nying sha nying gis za ba} in the older form of Tibetan signifies {rang sha rang gis za ba} one eating his own flesh, i.e., ruining himself.

186 ram bu|a glee, song, catch, roundel; {'degs pa} to join in singing, to take part in a song; {ram bu bteg} explained as {glu len grogs byed mkhan} a helper in a song, a joiner in singing.
186 ras ros|= {yo byad sna tshogs} different kinds of furniture, utensils, &c.: {ras ros thams cad mngon par gsogs shing} having collected different kinds of furniture, utensils, &c. (D.R.).
186 rdo dreg|({brag zhun lta bu} a kind of pitch) (Moon.) not as in Jä. the dirt on stone. {rdo dreg dug dang tshad pa rnying pa sel} pitch eradicates chronic inflamation and poison (Sman.).
186 rmyang ba|or {rmyeng ba} to bend towards; to stretch one's self, to stretch forward the neck as if to hear anybody speaking or whispering: {bya rmyang byed pa} to stretch, to yawn (Cs.).
186 sems rnal|(yoga) a peaceful state of mind, a concentrated mind. {sems rnal du phabs nas legs pa bsam dgos so} (Situ. 71) the mind to be brought into perfect rest must have good thoughts.
186 sne len|resp. ({mthong bzos}) attention to guests, hospitality, reception given to guests: {byang pa yon bdag rnams sne len mthong bzos bdag rkyen dgos pa ri rtsa ba yin pas} (D. Shel.).
186 sum pa|or {sums pa} 1. n. of a province and that of a monastery in Amdo. 2. acc. to Jä. adj. putrid, rancid, rotten. 3. vb. to bind or tie together, to draw together; to condense (Sch.).
186 thog grangs pa|1. to be the leader of, to lead against, to lead forward, to conduct: {shA kya seng chen dang bcas pas thog grangs kyis} and headed by Sakya together with Mahanama (Yig.).
186 zhim thig la|a medicinal herb the fruit of which is used in eye-disease: {zhim thig les mig gi ling thog len par byed} cataract of the eye is removed by the medicine called shim-thig-le.
187 bcos pa|SANST to refine; SANST, SANST to cure, remedy; healing or mending; SANST artificial, affected, feigned; mixed up: {mkhas kyang bcos su med/} he cannot be cured even by the wisest.
187 ber ka|= {ral ga} a branch; {ber ma}, {ber lcag} a stick or staff; {spa'i ber ma} cane, bamboo stick (Mil.); {ber ma lcag} a switch.\n\nSyn. {dbyug pa}; {'khar ba}; {'khar dbyug} (Moon.).
187 bka' log|= {grva log} (ta-log) one who has given up his religious vows; a Buddhist monk turned out of his monastery for misconduct. In Khams he is called bkah-log; in Middle Tibet ta-log.
187 bla gos|SANST upper garment which is of two forms: {rab byung gi bla gos} that worn by a Buddhist monk, and the other {khyim pa'i bla gos} the upper covering of the body used by lay folk.
187 blo bur|= {glo bur} SANST sudden, suddenly: {khyed de ltar gyi dad pa blo bur yin} thy present faith is but just sprung up. {blo bur du 'ongs} SANST, SANST comes all on a sudden; a guest.
187 bram ze li bi ka ra|‡ SANST n. of an Indian Brahman who taught Sanskrit to Thon-mi Sambhota early in the seventh century A.D. (Situ.).\n\n(EEE The original has Brahman for Brahman above.)
187 'breng pa|SANST leather or hide strap; {'breng zhags} SANST [bound, connected]S. {'breng hril} = {ko thag ril 'grim pa} straps or ropes made of hide thongs twisted together (S. kar. 179).
187 che long|= {drags pa} or {drags rim} SANST [sufficient, excessive, noble]S.: {che long don tsam mthong bas chog shes rnyed/} having perceived a sufficient meaning he obtained contentment.
187 chur ba|or {chur ra} SANST a kind of cheese or curd extracted from milk after boiling and evaporation: {chur ra stobs bskyed khu ba 'phel} gives strength and increases the seminal energy.
187 des pa|+\ngya nom pa SANST 1. fine, brave, noble, chaste (Cs.). 2. = {ngang rgyud bzang ba} or {gzhi bzang ba} of good nature; (K. d. {tsha} 166). {nges pa phun sum tshogs pa} consummate.
187 dpa' skong ba|= {nga rgyal 'joms pa} to humiliate, to humble, break the pride: {gzhan gyi bsam pa ma rung ba dag dpa' skong ba'i phyir du dpung bzhi'i dmag bshams te} (Hbrom. {kha}, 318).
187 dper na|or {dper} SANST, SANST for example; v. sub. {dpe}. {dper mtshon} = {dper bzhag pa} setting example. {dper yang} SANST [even comparison]S. {dper brjod pa} fit for being an example.
187 gad skyibs|a rock cavern; a place of shelter under the cleft or nook of a rock: {dngul gyi ljang pa de rnams gad skyibs shig tu bzhag} kept the bars of silver in the nook of a rocky hill.
187 gsang tshig|= {gsang gtam} secret speech: {snying la mod pa'i gsang tshig rnams/_ngan pa rnams la spel mi bya} (Sh. gya.) the secrets of one's heart, should not be revealed to the wicked.
187 gshin rje ma hA kA la|one of the most powerful sons of Mahadeva who carrying in his hand a huge club of the size of Sumeru mountain keeps the Asura in perpetual terror (K. g. {zha}, 317).
187 gsus khyim che ba|= {lto ba che ba} SANST a large belly: {gshin rje bshed sku mdog dmar la gsus khyim che ba} the red-coloured manifestation of the Lord of death has a huge belly (A. 17).
187 gzhongs|+\n= {ljongs} valley, basin of a river; also {yul gzhongs}. {gzhongs spyod pa} = {ljongs rgyu ba} gen. a monk who frequents small towns and villages moving among the country folk.
187 ji tsug|= {gang 'dra} how, like what? in what manner? {skyabs gnas thugs rje can rnams ci tsug la song /} (A. 128) "how the merciful ones, the refuge (of the helpless), have passed away!"
187 ko thud|a kind of tea, probably so called on account of being sold packed in hide cases; an inferior tea: {se se phur med pa'i ko thud la/} (Rtsii. 74)" to the cost of pressed brick-tea."
187 nang byan chud pa|+\n= {don thams cad rang dbang du 'du ba ste gzhan la 'dri mi dgos pa/} one who has mastered all meanings and does not require to ask others for explanation of the same.
187 ngo mi chod pa|= {ngo mi phod pa} or {ngo mi bzlog pa} SANST one who listens to or does a thing to please another which he would not otherwise have done; to be unable to refuse or oppose.
187 pho yig|the male letters of the Tibetan alphabet which are {ka}, {ca}, {ta}, {pa}, {tsa}, &c.; among the thirty letters the first of each group being regarded as a male letter (Situ. 60).
187 rdo rgyus|1. a medicinal stone (Moon.). This mineral cures swellings of the veins and sprains and contraction of the muscles (Sman.). 2. oath in contracting friendship to make it lasting.
187 rdzus ma|something counterfeit, feigned, dissembled: {rdzus ma'i mkhas pa} a master of dissimulation; {rdzus ma'i sprang po} a disguised beggar (Glr.); {mu tig rdzas ma} imitation pearls.
187 rked pa rgyur ba|(metaph.) to become a slave (female): {rked pa rgyur ba gzhu 'dra g.yog mor 'gyur/} a woman whose waist has become bent like a bow becomes a maid servant (K. d {go} 217).
187 rkyal pa|SANST a sack or leather bag, frq. is poetical term for the body or the five aggregates, i.e., {phung po mi gtsang rdzas kyi rkyal pa} "the body is a bag of unclean things" (Jä.).
187 sam Ta|a wooden board used as a school-slate in Tibet for drafting and computation. Acc. to Schr. {brtsam grva}, {sam khra}, or {lam dra} pocket-book, note-book, memorandum-book, tablets.
187 sgra dbyangs lha mo|the Goddess Sarasvati.\n\nSyn. {lha mo dbyangs can ma}; {dbyangs can ma}; {tshangs sras mo}; {mtsho byung lha mo}; {tshangs ba'i sras mo}; {ngag dbang lha mo} (Moon.).
187 sgyel ba|pf. and fut. {bsgyel}, transit. form of {'gyel ba}, to throw down; to over-turn; to lay or put down (a bottle, a book); to thwart (the charm of an enemy); to kill (horses) (Jä.).
187 spras|1. n. of a place in {'phan yul} in Tibet. {spras kyi bra'i thang} birthplace of To-wa Rin-chen gsal (a pupil of Bromston in Hphan-yul (Loo. {za}, 2.). 2. = {rgyan} ornament (Moon.).
187 stag gzig|({sa bdag}) lit. "tiger-leopard." 1. n. of a demi-god residing in the nether world. 2. a corruption of the name Tajik by which Persia and the Persians are known to the Tibetans.
187 thams cad mkhyen pa|= {kun mkhyen} SANST the omniscient, the all-knower, an epithet of Buddhas and Bodhisattvas. The incarnate lamas of Tibet are also by courtesy addressed by this title.
187 thur po|the lowest part, the lower side (of a hill): {thur thur gyi thur po la} at the very lowest possible point, in the bottom-most part (e.g., of a deep ravine between two hill-sides).
187 tsho ba|= {lus rgyags} fat, corpulent, also corpulency. Acc. to Jä. fat, greasy: {tsho 'dug mi 'dug} or {bud ma bud} is it fat or not? {tsho khu} fat gravy; {tsho ldir} unwieldy with fat.
188 bdud rtsi gangs sham|vegetable medicine growing on the snow-line in the Himalaya or in Tibet. {bdud rtsi chos sman} vegetable elixir used as an antidote against the attack of evil spirits.
188 bka' rgyud rnam rgyal|the Bkah-rgyud, Chief Lama whom the Mongol Chief Gushi Khan dethroned after overthrowing the power of Sde-pa Gtsao-pa the ruler of Tsang and Ü in 1643 A.D. (Loo. 13).
188 byang chub lam sgron|the great work of Atisa which was written in Sanskrit during his residence in the golden monastery of Thoding or Tholing in W. Tibet, still an important establishment.
188 chu 'khor|SANST, SANST, SANST a whirlpool, an eddy. ["a water-goer," i.e., a heron or a leech]S.\n\nSyn. {klong 'khor}; {'khyim pa}; {zeg ma'i lte}; {chu yi 'khor lo}; {'khor chu} (Moon.).
188 dbang ldan me tog|n. of a flower and also that of a world of Bon mythology (G. Bon.). {dbang ldan me tog me 'od gsal} a fancied world believed to exist to the west of this world (G. Bon.).
188 dur ba dkar po|1. SANST the blue or white flowering durwa; Panicum dactylon. 2. SANST, SANST other white species of durwa.\n\nSyn. {brtson 'grus brgya ba}; {glang spu skyes}; {bya yi mig}.
188 dus ma yin par za ba|SANST taking food untimely, i.e., not at the fixed or prescribed time or hour; {dus min shes pa} SANST one who knows the fixed times or seasons; a cock; an astrologer.
188 gdang ba|pf. {gdangs pa} SANST; {kha gdang ba} to gape, to open wide (the mouth and nostrils), to stretch; {lag pa gdangs} stretched apart the arms; {bsnyung gzhi gdangs} cured of disease.
188 gser chu|liquid gold; gilding. Name of a river between Ladak and Lahul where the people of Lahul paid tribute in gold to former kings of Ladak. {gser chu gtang ba} SANST to gild with gold.
188 hva|I: 1. in Budh.: {hva zhes pa ni bod pa mi dmigs pa'i phyir chos thams cad kyi sgo'o} (Hbum. {ga}, 283). 2. (Chinese) a picture, a painting.\n\nII: 1. in {gos gyi hva} collar of a coat.
188 'jigs par 'gyur|SANST becomes frightened; {'jigs par byed} SANST frightened.\n\n(EEE The original gives the transliteration of the headword as "hjigs-par-hyyur" which is clearly in error.)
188 kha nyung|sparing of words; laconic (Sch.): {kha nyung lag gtsang}, {kha mang po mi lab mkhan dang rkun ma ma rgyag pa} is one who does not speak many words and who does not act the thief.
188 kha rtsang|= {kha sang} yesterday forenoon: {kha rtsang gi byis pa} the boy that was here yesterday forenoon (A.); also the day before yesterday; {khar sang gza' nyi ma} last Sunday (Jä.).
188 'khor los sgyur rgyal gyi btsun mo|the wife of the Universal Emperor.\n\nSyn. {mi yi lha mo}; {bud med rin chen}; {gnam bskos ma}; {lhag pa'i dbang phyug ma}; {'jig rten btsun mo} (Moon.).
188 'khor los 'tsho|v. {rdza mkhan}, a potter; one who lives by turning the (potter's) wheel (Moon.).\n\n(EEE {rdza mkhan} does not occur as a headword in the dictionary but see under {rdza}.)
188 'khul ba|acc. to Oag. to subdue; to subject one by argument and language to service; acc. to Cs. to be uneasy about; {khral 'khul ba} acc. to Jä. perh. to force a tax, a rate, on a person.
188 mda' 'joms|1. SANST the great Tantrik Buddhist Sage who was abbot of Nalendra and from whom Nagarjuna derived his mystical knowledge of Buddhism. 2. n. of medicinal root = {dur byid sman}.
188 mthu ba|SANST ({mthu sgrub mkhan}) an exorcist, one who practises witchcraft. {mthu bo che sngags pa}, {sngags chen} one versed in mysticism, in the Tantrik cult, an exorcist lama (Moon.).
188 mu tig can|‡ one of the Tibetan kings; {chab srid sna nam la ster nges snyam ste mu tig btsan po la gsol bas} having decided to make over the kingdom to Snanam he petitioned Mutig Tsan-po.
188 ngogs|SANST the bank of a river or lake; {'jug ngogs} = {chu ngogs} a place on the bank of a river where people crossing it; land. Acc. to Jä. mountain side; slope; ghaut.\n\nSyn. {'gram}.
188 phyag cha|any manual tool or implement, resp. for {lag cha}. {phyag chas} instruments (symb. of attributes) carried in the hand, or used in performing religious dances, cf. {phyag mtshan}.
188 rnga yab|SANST, SANST 1. lit. "the father of tails," i.e., a yak's tail, used for fanning and sometimes for dusting. 2. n. of a fabulous continent said to exist to the north of Jambudvipa.

191 sde pa gtsang pa|the powerful chief who had established his sway over Tibet in the beginning of the 17th century. He was killed by the Zungarian chief Gushi-khan in 1643 A.D. (Loo. {'a}, 13).
191 sgom chen|1. a Buddhist ascetic who remains absorbed in deep meditation. 2. species of fieldmouse, Lagomys badius, so called from its hybernating disposition. See Hooker's Himalayan Journals.

191 yol go|or {yol ma} a cup or vessel of precious stone or metal (Yig.). Acc. to Schtr., earthenware, crockery; {dkar yol} china-ware, porcelain, frq.; {yol gor} cup, bowl. {yol sgo} = {yol go}.
191 zung gzug|= {yel 'chos} SANST, SANST, SANST technical term of practical mysticism, the forcing of the mind ({sems}) into the principal artery, in order to prevent distraction (of mind) (Jä.).
192 bco lnga mchod pa|the religious service that is observed on the fifteenth of the first Tibetan month (February-March) at Lhasa when the Kinkhording, the grand temple of Buddha, is illuminated.
192 brtad|SANST a kind of formal curse, which consists in hiding the effigy and name of an enemy in the ground and imploring some deity to kill him: {brtad 'jug pa} to perform that ceremony (Jä.).
192 bsgribs pa'i lung du mi ston pa|SANST to abstain from obscure prediction: {dge mi dge gang yang min pa la lung ma bstan}: do not prophesy or predict what is not known either to be good or bad.
192 bskang gso|yi dam mkha' 'gro chos skyong rnams la bskang gso rgyas pa to make copious religious services to the tutelar deities, angels, and the guardian spirits of the ten quarters (Shil. 9).
192 bslu rdo|fig. temptation, bait, lit. the stone that is thrown at a dog to divert his attention: {'khor ba'i bslu rdo spangs pa yin} I have left off the temptations of worldly life (Khrid. 18).
192 can bzhi rgyal po|believe to be an incarnation of Padma Sambhava or Guru rin-po-che. {can bzhi rgyal pos dgra bgegs ru dra sgrol/} saves one from enemies, evil spirits and Rudra (Lh. kar. 35).
192 'ded sbyangs|clever in making collection of rents or debts: {lhag byas byung gi chad rnams 'ded sbyangs babs kyi gzhi} the measures of excess and the budget of skilful collection (D. Shel. 8).
192 dgos 'dod|1. necessary expenses; what is wished for as very necessary (Cs.). 2. {dgos 'dod} wishes and wants: {dgos 'dod 'byung ba'i dpal} a treasure out of which all wishes and wants are met.
192 dgun smad|SANST the after part of the winter season; {dgun stod kha dus hemanta} time of snow in the beginning winter; {dgun smad grang dus} time of cold, about the end of the winter (Rtsii.).
192 dgu pa|the ninth; having, comprising, measuring nine, e.g., {khru dgu pa} measuring nine cubits (in length, height, etc.); {dgu bo} SANST the ninth, the nine, those nine; {lan dgu} nine times.
192 dka' bcu|SANST ten ascetical hardships; a Buddhist scholar who has acquired such great proficiency in sacred literature as to be able to interpret the meanings of a term in ten different ways.
192 dkyil 'khor can|SANST anything that has a circular and mystical figure on it; also any Tantrik deity placed to be worshipped on the plane of his fancied celestial mansion traced on the ground.
192 dmigs gsal|or {dmigs kyi gsal} clear to the mind: {sger du byed 'os kyi dmigs gsal byung na ma gtogs} unless it is clear that the work should be done privately or confidentially (D. Shel. 12).
192 'dor byed|SANST 1. one who forsakes or abandons. 2. met. blood. 3. SANST; {spyi zhur gyi shing} the spyi-shur plant of Tibet (Moon.). [the tree Terminalia tomentosa, or Marsilea quadrifolia]S.
192 dor ma|breeches, trowsers; {dor thung} short breeches; {dor ring} long drawers; {snam dor} breeches made of thick serge cloth; {dor rta} that part of the breeches which covers the privy parts.
192 gnya' rengs|stiff-necked, obstinate: {ngan pa gnya' rengs ser smug gtam 'di nyon} (Rdsa. 28) Ser-smug, thou obstinate wretch, listen to this my word. {gnya' rengs can} stiff-necked, obstinate.
192 grung po|I: (duo-po) = {grung ba}, {skyang po}, {rig pa grims pa} 1. very intelligent; SANST clever; wise; prudent. 2. meek; mild; gentle (Cs.).\n\nII: the corn seed that is not rotten (Jig.).
192 'jam mgon bla ma|an address of politeness to the hierarchs of the Sakya school.\n\n(EEE The original gives the transliteration of the headword as "hjam-mgon bla-ma" which is clearly in error.)
192 ka ma rtsi|‡ SANST a kind of medicinal plant: {ka ma tsi'i rtsa ba spyi bor blang na gnyid du 'gyur/} "if the root of ka-ma-tsi be placed on the top of the head, sleep arises" (K. g. {ca} 56).
192 ke sha|SANST hair; mane; {yi ge ke sha can} letters which are surmounted with double e{_au} sign called hgreo-bu or o{_au} sign called naro. Signs for long accentuation are also called ke-sha.
192 kun dga' ra ba|= {gling dga'} SANST a grove; any pleasure-grove containing groups of trees, flower beds, artificial lakes, garden houses, shady walks, &c., often surrounded by a wall or fence.
192 las kyi mtha'|SANST completion of a work, efficiency; {de ltar bzo dang las kyi mtha'i brtan bcos la mkhas pa} and so he was versed in works treating of technical arts and agriculture (A. 37).
192 lha mo dung gi nu zho can|an officinal herb growing in the clefts of rocks and with leaves resembling those of the bamboo and yielding milky juice after incision; is used in ulcers and wounds.
192 longs|imp. of {long ba}: rise up, awake, get up! {nang nas longs shog} let him come out from in side or from his house; {da lta longs la lam du bzhugs} now get up and wait in the way (A. 129).
192 ltong ga|1. notch, incision, indentation; {mda' stong} the notch in an arrow. 2. a depression; {ri ltong} depression in a ridge of mountains; {la ltong} the indentation of mountain-pass (Jä.).
192 mdom|or {mdoms} sometimes written for {'dom} a measure ({'jal byed}) equal to six feet [SANST a fathom or the space between the tips of the fingers of either hand when the arms are extended]S.
192 nang 'khor|domestic attendants and officers, such as {gsol dpon}, {gzim dpon}, etc.: {nang 'khor ba la yang gsung mi gtong ba} he does not even say anything to his domestic attendants (A. 95).
192 phyag phyi|= {zhabs phyi} attendant, man-servant; {phyag phyi byed pa} to be a servant. {phyag phyi la}or {phyag phyir 'breng ba} to be a follower (of a lama); train of servant, retinue (Jä.).
192 ral lcang|a weeping willow-tree, but according to Jä. a particular willow planted at the birth of a child and under which a lock of the child's hair is buried when it is seven years old in Ld.
192 rdog pa|any action with the foot, but chiefly a footstep; a stride or pace: {rdog pa 'bor ba} to step, to pace, to walk (Cs.); {rdog pa rgyab pa} to stamp on the ground with the feet, to kick.
192 rdos pa|1. adj. swollen, bloated, like to burst: {lus rdos che ba} very corpulent body. 2. vb. n. to break, burst, flow out: {lbu ba rdos pa} the bursting of a bubble. {dbugs rdos pa} to pant.
192 rtsa ba'i sde|the four earliest divisions in the Buddhist society: (1) {thams cad yod par smra ba} SANST; (2) {phal chen sde ba} SANST; (3) {mang pos bkur ba} SANST; (4) {gnas brtan pa} SANST.
192 sger don|one's own interest, private or special reason or object: {sger gzhung med du ba gnam btang} neither private nor public (but an independent family) sending forth smoke from house-fire.
192 spyan drug|acc. to the Bon there are six glances or visions, viz.: {bon gyi spyan}; {ye shes kyi spyan}; {rig pa'i spyan}; {thugs rje'i spyan}; {sprul pa'i spyan}; {shes rab kyi spyan} (D.R.).
192 srid sgrub|SANST, SANST 1. white. 2. n. of a celebrated mathematician who lived during Buddha Gautama's time (K. d. {kha}, 113), [the astrologer Arjuna was the Buddha's mathematical teacher]S.
192 tA la'i phreng ba|n. of a fabulous mountain situated five thousand yojana beyond the southern ocean. {tA la'i phreng ba zhes bya ba'i ri ring du dpag tshad stong phrag lnga/} (K. d. {ra} 275).
192 tshangs 'khor|SANST the second of the first Dhyana heavens v. {bsam gtan dang po} (M.V.).\n\n(EEE {bsam gtan dang po} does not occur as a headword in the dictionary but see under {bsam gtan}.)
192 tshis|1. acc. Jä.: prob. secondary form of {rtsis}. 2. = {so nam gyi las} work of husbandry. 3. {tshis su} = {grogs su} in friendship: {thams cad nas khyed kyi tshis su ci 'gro byed} (A. 133).
192 zla gam|1. SANST semi-circular; semi-circular disk, the appearance of the eighth phase of the moon. 2. the cloak which the monk of the Gelug-pa sect wears at a religious service only (Rtsii.).
193 ban glang|+\n= {ba glang} ox, bull.\n\n(EEE the original has {ban klang} in the Tibetan and ban glang for the transliteration. The transliterations is correct so the headword has been changed.)
193 dran ma|the mind, memory: {dran ma bzang} good memory; {dran las} SANST from memory, from consciousness; conscious state; {dran had kyi zin pa} sudden recollection; remembering all on a sudden.
193 'dud pa|pf. and fut. {btud} SANST to bend, to make a bow; {zhabs la 'dud pa} to bow at a person's feet (Oag. 39); {rna ba 'dud} to incline one's ears to hear; {rab tu 'dud pa} SANST salutation.
193 gling log|revolution; internal dissension: {der 'bri khung pa la gling log chen po byung} there arose much civil disturbance there in Dikhuo, i.e., among the members of the Hbri-khuo monastery.
193 'gog byed|SANST discipline, and from {'gog pa}, there arise 1. {zhi ba} SANST peace; 2. {gya nom pa} = {phun sum tshogs pa} SANST perfected state. 3. {nges par 'byung ba} SANST firm conviction.
193 grva tshang|(ta-tshao) SANST school where monks are instructed in sacred literature; a section in a great monastery, where the monks belonging to one particular school of studies live together.
193 gtib pa|or {gtibs pa} to be gathering (of clouds); {sprin phung gtib pa} thick clouds gathering; {bdug spos sprin bzhin gtib} incense passes along like clouds; {mun pa gtib} darkness envelopes.
193 gtum mo|SANST, SANST, SANST, SANST 1. a fierce or violent woman, a female of the Candala tribe, etc. 2. as an adj. violent, fearful; {rlung gtum mo} a violent wind, a hurricane. 3. mystic heat.
193 g.yem pa|or {log g.yem} 1. = {'dod log} or {'dod pa log par g.yem pa} fornication, incest, adultery. {g.yem byed pa} to commit adultery, fornication. 2. SANST false dealings, acting wrongfully.
193 ka re|probably {ga re}. The use of the latter is very common in Eastern Tibet. In Sikkim they say {ka te}, what? which? {au pa shi ka khyod ka re dga'} Upasaka, in what do you delight? (A. 94).
193 kha sbyar|or {kha sbyar ba} the mouth of a vessel or box closed or shut up: {zangs chen kha sbyar rin chen sil mas bkang} a covered copper vessel filled with precious things, etc. (G. kah. 77).
193 lca ba|1. a sort of carrot (Cs.) 2. SANST a garment made for wool or felt: {lca bas chu ser mkhal rked grang ba sel/} felt cures watery discharges, kidney disease, and cold in the loins (Med.).
193 ldug pa|or {ldugs}, pf. {ldugs} or {blugs} (usual form), fut. {blug}, imp. {blug} or {blugs}, col. {blug pa}: to pour out or into, to sprinkle, to strew; to cast, to found (metal), cf. {blugs}.
193 lon|1. news, tidings, message: {lon bzang} good news, {lon spring} to give notice, send word, send a message; {lon skyur ba} to give a reply; {lon zhig khyer la shog} let me know, send me word.
193 lums|({sman dpyad}) a bath used as a medical cure; {chu tshan gyi lums} a hot-bath; {bdud rtsi lnga lums} a bath in which the infusion of plants is used five; {brtsings pa'i lums} fomentations.
193 mtshog ma|or {mtshag gseng} 1. the hair of the head, only for a length of three inches from the root. 2. = {tshangs pa'i bu ga} 'spot or tender part of the head,' vacancy in the infant cranium.

193 na tshod gnas pa|lang tsho dar ba SANST a youth (Moon.) [a youthful maiden]S. {na tshod yol} passed youth, one whose youth is over; but acc. to Rtsii. an old man between 60 and 72 years of age.
193 ngar ngar po|hoarse, husky, wheezing, e.g., in old age (Thgy.); {ngar glud} hoarseness and phlegm (Med.); {gre ba ngar ba} a hoarse throat (Med.; Jä.); {ngar ngar 'khun sgra} a hoarse groaning.
193 'phan po|or {'phan yul} ({lha sa'i nye 'dab phyogs su yod pa'i yul zhig}) n. of the nearest alpine valley north of Lhasa. {'phan yul grab dkar} one of the thirty holy places of Bon (G. Bon. 4).

193 sgrub 'chag|building or making and dismantling or destroying; the term is defined in {gsar ba sgrub rgyu dang rnying pa nas mar 'chag rgyu} constructing a new one and breaking down the old one.

193 spyom pa|= {smod pa} slander, also vb. with pf. {spyoms} to boast, to exhibit with ostentation; sbst. {spyoms} self-praise, boasting (Jä.); {spyoms dang bcas ma bya'o} you must not be boastful.
193 srus|unripe ears of wheat, etc., unripe grains of Indian corn, wheat &c. {'bras kyi srus} an unripe shelled grain of rice.\n\nSyn. {so ma}; {ma nyams pa}; {rma med}; {byis pa zad byed} (Moon.).

194 dun pa|(for {bdun pa}) great diligence, assiduity; {'dun pa drag po} very diligent; in W. (cf. {'dun pa} and {rtun pa}).\n\n(EEE The original has "and {rtun}).", but {rtun pa} is clearly meant.)
194 gam 'brog|a dairy in the neighbourhood of one's residence. {gam 'brog rgyang 'brog bzang ba rtsa yi dge_/}. Near and distant dairy farms become thriving through the abundance of pastures (Jig.).
194 ga na|gang na SANST where? {ga na ba} and {gang na ba}, the same as a sbst., the whereabouts of a person, his place of residence: {rgyal po ga na bar der song /} he went here where the king was.
194 gon pa|({gyon pa}) to put on clothes, shoes, etc.; {gon pa 'dra ba re re} the cost of a set of anything to wear (Rtsii.); {mgo la zhva gon pa} to put a cap on the head. 2. coat, clothing (Sch.).
194 gra sdebs|proper order, arrangement; also {mi mang kha sdebs} uniform deposition: {mdun dang log g.yas g.yon gyi gra sdebs} the arrangement in the front and of the right and left sides (Rtsii.).

194 lag ldan|SANST, SANST having a hand or trunk, hence as met. = elephant; {lag ldan ma} = {glang mo} she-elephant (Moon.). {lag ldan ra ba} elephant stable, place where elephants are kept (Moon.).
194 mnga'|resp. for {dbang} might, dominion, sway, power; {mnga' mdzad pa} to govern, to rule; {mnga' brnyes pa} to obtain power; {mnga' sgyur ba} to have mastered a thing; to understand thoroughly.
194 ngan spong skyes|= {dga' byed dgra sta can} or {ngan spong bu} Parasu Rama; {rdul can ma'i bu} the son of Rdul-can-ma (Moon.); an epithet of Sukra and also of the planet Venus ({gza' pa sangs}).

194 nyin mo|SANST, SANST, SANST, SANST the day; the time lighted or illuminated by the sun. {'di na mdangs 'bar dang}, {gsal bar snang dang snang ldan dang}, {mun sel padma bzhad pa'i dus} (Rtsii.).
194 phung pa|= {brlag pa} spoilt, blown out, destroyed, lost, etc. {phung krol} = {'thab krol} [SANST useless]S.; also = {nyes pa mang po'i rtsa ba} SANST the cause or root of many evils and faults.
194 rag pa|1. vb. W. for {reg pa} to touch, feel, and in a more generalized sense = {'tshhor ba} to perceive, to scent, taste, hear, see. 2. adj. dark-russet, brownish, of horses, rocks, etc. (Jä.).
194 rdog 'gril ba|= {ha cang zhib rtsis byed pa} to enumerate exactly, scrutinize carefully; formed into minute grain: {nyung dkar las rdog 'gril ba} even more-fully grained than white mustard seed.
